pull.title: init: Remove deprecated args from hidden args
pull.body: The args have been deprecated since 0.17 (maybe longer) and since we reject unknown args, there is no need to add deprecated args to the list of hidden args and then hand-craft an error message if a user provides them.

verification.payload:
tree 3e7b4a54e10385aab0ad260eb4d1ec35764e2e1f
parent d26278988fbfc71dc558f7b2c60a184e8091450b
author MarcoFalke <falke.marco@gmail.com> 1537389470 -0400
committer MarcoFalke <falke.marco@gmail.com> 1537390052 -0400

init: Remove deprecated args from hidden args

events.message: init: Remove deprecated args from hidden args

events.body:
`-rpcssl`, wow, that one has been gone for a whileâ€¦

ACK
ACK fa910e4, verified all occurrences of these deprecated args were removed.
I think you can also remove `-usehd`, since it doesn't have any effect from 0.16 onwards.

@jnewbery It is currently used to inform the user of "You can't enable/disable HD on an already existing non-HD/HD wallet". I think it gives users a feeling of assurance that their existing wallet file is indeed hd or non-hd.
I'll leave the decision whether this can be removed to the wallet-people.

issue.title: [wallet] Remove -usehd
issue.body: `-usehd` is no longer used (except to tell the user that they've set it incorrectly for the wallet that they're loading). Remove it (in the same spirit as #14272)

issue.title: Merge bitcoin#14272: init: Remove deprecated args from hidden args
issue.body:
Merge #14272: init: Remove deprecated args from hidden args

fa910e4301 init: Remove deprecated args from hidden args (MarcoFalke)

Pull request description:

  The args have been deprecated since 0.17 (maybe longer) and since we reject unknown args, there is no need to add deprecated args to the list of hidden args and then hand-craft an error message if a user provides them.

Tree-SHA512: 3a3191439ab0d7969fb72801d097bd86998524f84b3819380224f746cbe4b0f57beec1ad34744424f6587038035b0ddf418ad13171a8d9c3b97b4f3b7b3222a3

comments.body: Won't this just yield a warning now?
Not that I am aware of
If the user has `tor=1` in bitcoin.conf, where will the InitError come from?

Oh, I was testing `src/qt/bitcoin-qt -notor`, which gave me and still gives

![screenshot from 2018-12-20 20-07-05](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/6399679/50305358-72be0600-04f7-11e9-9b03-352a33c0d436.png)
